titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Larry LeSueur papers, 1935-2003 MS2307
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:41:52 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

physdesc.extent: 17 document boxes, 3 flat boxes, and 1 film

did.abstract: Laurence Edward "Larry" LeSueur was a Peabody-award winning radio correspondent best known as one of "Murrow's Boys," a band of international correspondents assembled in Europe before and during World War II by Edward R. Murrow for CBS. On D-Day, June 6, 1944, LeSueur was one of the first journalists to land at Normandy and report back news of the battle to Americans at home. This collection contains typewritten scripts, correspondence, articles, journals, audiocassettes and audio reels, and artifacts documenting LeSueur's 40-year career as a radio correspondent. Radio scripts and newspaper clippings include LeSueur's vivid accounts of war, written while he was stationed abroad from 1939 through the end of World War II. Other scripts, delivered while LeSueur was a White House correspondent, feature his first-person descriptions of business at the highest levels of government. The material dates from 1935 to 2003.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains typewritten scripts, correspondence, articles, journals, audiocassettes and audio reels, and artifacts documenting LeSueur's 40-year careeer as a radio correspondent. Radio scripts and newspaper clippings include LeSueur's vivid accounts of war, written while he was stationed abroad from 1939 through the end of World War II. Other scripts, delivered while LeSueur was a White House correspondent, feature his first-person descriptions of business at the highest levels of government. In addition, audiocassettes and audio reels include some of LeSueur's broadcasts, as well as oral histories, interviews, and memories of D-Day. The material dates from 1935 to 2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Laurence Edward "Larry" LeSueur was a Peabody-award winning radio correspondent best known as one of "Murrow's Boys," a band of international correspondents assembled in Europe before and during World War II by Edward R. Murrow. He was born in New York in 1909, and began his career as a print journalist for United Press in the 1930s. He left New York for London in 1939, introduced himself to Murrow, and secured a position with him on the CBS Radio Network. He reported from the Russian front in 1941 and 1942, with a weekly radio broadcast called "An American in Russia," and wrote a book on the experience called Twelve Months that Changed the World, published in 1943.

On D-Day, June 6, 1944, LeSueur was one of the first journalists to land at Normandy and report back news of the battle to Americans at home. He covered Europe throughout the war, including broadcasting news of the liberation of Paris. After the war, LeSueur continued broadcasting for CBS Radio as White House correspondent, most notably from the Paris Peace Conference. He left CBS in 1963 but continued covering the White House, for Voice of America, until his retirement in 1984. He died on February 5, 2003 at the age of 93.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: Radio scripts, Subject files, Notebooks and journals, Audiovisual, Artifacts, and Clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains typed scripts prepared by LeSueur for radio broadcasts, first for CBS News and then for Voice of America. Many include handwritten edits. Topics of interest include: wartime Russia, the Battle of Normandy, wartime London, the Paris Peace Conference, and the administrations of American presidents Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter, and Reagan. They date from 1942 to 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains collected articles, written histories, correspondence, and biographical information. Major topics of interest include Edward R. Murrow, the invasion of Normandy on D-Day, and the Paris Peace Conference of 1946. Material dates from 1944 to 2003.

did.unittitle: American Society of the French Legion of Honor
"Memories of Your Father" [Edward R. Murrow] by Chester S. Williams
"The Soviet Army" by Larry Le Sueur
Trip to Asia with President Johnson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains notebooks, journals, appointment books, passports, press passes, and licenses used by LeSueur from 1941 to 1985 while a radio correspondent.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: All cassettes are contained in one box without arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains audiocassettes and audio reels of LeSueur including news broadcasts, interviews, and oral histories. The material dates from 1935 to 1993. Some cassettes are copies of early broadcasts originally recorded on other audio formats.

did.unittitle: Normandy Remembered: 50th Anniversary by Colonel Barney and Vada Oldfield [1 of 2]
did.abstract: A video commemoration of the 50th anniversary of D-Day and the four Nebraska natives who died in the invasion. Produced by Colonel Barney and Vada Oldfield in association with the Nebraska Normandy Scholarship Fund of the University Nebraska Foundation. 37 minutes

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Artifacts are housed according to size and material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains awards and certificates, medallions, badges, key fobs, and other small items used by or given to LeSueur during the course of his broadcast career. Most material is undated but appears to date from the 1960s to 1984.

did.unittitle: Oversize photo of LeSueur and Senator Baker
Oversize magazines with memorial articles for President Kennedy
Oversize scrapbook of photos from President Johnson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains newspaper clippings both by and about LeSueur, as well as clippings about the Battle of Normandy and about President John F. Kennedy. They date from 1940 to 1988. Most of these clippings are photocopies of originals that were compromised by mold and brittle paper.
